If this is how China treats its own people, I think it’s fair to ask: What kind of risks are our athletes facing as they participate in the Olympic Games?

I urge my colleagues to think beyond the passions of the moment and do what’s best for our country in the long term.
 
Leave the filibuster in place. Democrats may want to use it again as soon as next year.

Bipartisanship would become a relic of the past.
 
I know Democrats don’t want that to happen. I don’t want it to happen, either.
When Republicans were in the majority, we said we wouldn’t abolish the legislative filibuster, and we kept our word.

This is not a debate about some arcane Senate rule.
 
This is about protecting the rights of the minority in our democracy.
 
This is about providing stability and certainty to our people.

The truth is that some of my Democratic colleagues want to remake the American system only in their own image, not considering the views of about half of our citizens.

To do that, they have to take an ax to the filibuster.
Their argument is that lawmakers in red states are trying to make it harder for people to vote, and so it’s necessary for Washington Democrats to take over election administration in all 50 states.

Democrats were perfectly happy to use the filibuster literally hundreds of times during the four years of the Trump presidency, when the Majority Leader was the Minority Leader and Republicans had even larger majorities in Congress.
The first part of that simply isn’t true. The right to vote is not under assault.

But because the rules don’t allow them to pass their federal takeover of elections or any of their other reckless policies in a 50-50 Senate, many of my Dem colleagues are flip-flopping to oppose the filibuster.

President Biden wants to pass a New Deal. In fact, the reckless spending the president is pushing for dwarfs the New Deal.

Back then the New Deal passed the on the back of Dem supermajorities, but today we have a 50-50 Senate and the Dem majority is razor thin.
The American people voted for bipartisanship and compromise in the United States Congress, not a blanket mandate for progressives to reorganize American life as they see fit.

And Congress would embrace a decision by the Biden administration to remain committed to nuclear modernization.
I believe Congress will continue to support modernizing our nuclear enterprise, in order to ensure that we have a capable and effective deterrent, supported by a modern infrastructure.
The decisions we make today will define the deterrent we field in the next fifteen years. We expect this force to be the bedrock of our national security for at least the next four decades.

It’s clear that nuclear deterrence will continue to be vital to our security for the foreseeable future. The current modernization program of record is the most prudent and cost-effective approach to ensuring that our nation continues to field a capable nuclear deterrent.

Some of my colleagues argue that canceling U.S. modernization programs could inspire Russia and China to do the same and create an opening for arms control negotiations.
 
However, looking at the behavior of China and Russia over the past 25 years, this is clearly not the case.
Failing to modernize, and allowing our forces to age until they become obsolete, only makes future arms control agreements less likely—not more.
We continue to read reports of China building up its nuclear arsenal. This is not the time to let our deterrent age out.

In anticipation of the Nuclear Posture Review, we’ve seen renewed debate on many modernization programs. However, I remain confident that the Biden administration will continue on the modernization path set by the Obama administration and followed by the Trump administration.

The outbreak of COVID-19 led to fewer flights out of many Nebraska airports, putting them at risk of receiving far less federal infrastructure formula funding.
 
I am pleased, that my AIR Act was included in the COVID relief package.

Directors of Nebraska’s airports have expressed how important this bill is to them. Now our airports with have the certainty they need to plan for future projects.
 
Read more here: https://t.co/qLVlFTkOUH
Learn more about how this relief package will benefit our state: https://t.co/94LgQPHjVu

In this latest COVID relief package, key priorities I have been working on to benefit Nebraska passed:
➡️ 15% temporary increase in SNAP

➡️ $13 billion for ag producers

➡️ Support for Nebraska airports

➡️ $15 million to speed up medical surge capacity and offer @UNMC the chance to participate.

➡️ The REEF Act, which will benefit railroaders by ensuring they receive unemployment and sickness benefits.
 
➡️ A five-year extension of my Paid Family Leave tax credit, America’s first such nationwide policy.

Last night, Congress passed an additional relief package which will help Nebraska schools, farmers, hospitals, and small businesses. It will also support vaccine distribution. 
 
American people needed this relief. While it took too long, I'm glad we could get it done.
Whether it’s caring for elderly parents or taking care of sick children working Americans will benefit from the flexibility my program offers.

This extension means businesses will be able to take advantage of this program and offer paid family leave to their employees who are caring for their families while juggling workplace responsibilities.
I am very happy to report that the COVID relief bill also includes a five-year extension of my paid family leave tax credit program, the first EVER U.S. nationwide PFL policy.
It includes the bipartisan REEF Act, which I was proud to cosponsor, that will help ensure during this pandemic that railroaders receive the full unemployment and sickness benefits they deserve.

It provides $15 million to speed implementation of the medical surge capacity pilot I included in #FY21NDAA, enhancing civ/mil partnerships to improve federal pandemic response. This will offer universities like @UNMC the chance to participate.
The legislation includes my AIR Act, which will provide Nebraska airports with more certainty during this pandemic and ensure they plan for future infrastructure projects.
The text of the COVID-19 relief package has been released. This legislation will bring much-needed help to our families, schools, hospitals, and businesses who have been hit hard by this virus.
I am really pleased this bill includes essential priorities I have been working on that will benefit Nebraskans, including:
The package includes a 15% increase in SNAP benefits to help struggling families who are food insecure during this pandemic. This has been a priority of mine, and I am glad to see it was included.
